description:
Sapajus apella, also known as the tufted capuchin or the brown capuchin, is a species of New World monkey native to the tropical forests of South America. It belongs to the genus Sapajus, which is part of the family Cebidae.

The Sapajus apella is a medium-sized primate, typically weighing between 2.5 to 4.5 kilograms. It has a robust build with a rounded head and a distinctive tuft of hair on its forehead, which gives it its common name "tufted capuchin." The species is known for its dexterous hands and fingers, which it uses for a variety of tasks, including foraging, tool use, and social interactions.

Sapajus apella is an omnivorous species, feeding on a wide range of plant and animal matter, including fruits, seeds, insects, small vertebrates, and even small monkeys. It is known for its complex social behavior, living in multi-male, multi-female groups with complex dominance hierarchies and a variety of communication signals, including vocalizations and facial expressions.

The species is widely distributed throughout the Amazon Basin and other parts of South America, and it is considered a species of least concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). However, its populations are threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation due to deforestation and human activities.
